message: Hi, folks. How does everyone manage all their vim config files?
I'm also curious about dependencies. There are lots of great .vim files that I use that are always being updated. it would be awesome if there was an easy way to keep those all up to date
I'd like to store my configs in version contro. What have people found works best?
maybe I just want a package manager
I do it :) https://github.com/nekrox/dot-vim

Yes, I store my vim files in a "dotfiles" group in a personal subversion repository. I have a working copy in ~/.vim on my various machines. My .vimrc file is in ~/.vim/vimrc, but I have it symlinked at ~/.vimrc. This makes it easy to commit and update inside the ~/.vim directory.
@sumpygump same here, and my .vim/* is under git control

I use Mercurial, and store not just .vim/ and .vimrc, but also bash profile, functions, aliases, and a range of other config files. I do it by having a Config/ repo, which contains a script to symlink files to where they need to be (e.g. symlinking ~/.vim to ~/Config/vim). As long as vim versions are similar enough across your machines, this works well.
I modeled it after my zshd setup (https://github.com/mwhooker/zshd), which is in turn borrowed from ideas like these ;)
excellent advice. I just uploaded my config to https://github.com/mwhooker/vimrc

Basically, you're crazy if you don't keep your dotfiles under version control.  Personally, I check them out in one folder, and then symlink the home dir versions to the checked out versions, but I have in the past, and still know people that just check out their repos to ~.  It's not as many files as it seems.  .vimrc, the .vim folder, maybe two files for shell stuff, then a few others for whatever.
I solve this in two parts:

1. All my config files (.vimrc, .vim, .bashrc, etc) are in a dropbox folder, that I just softlink to.
2. I've made a little script that uses pathogen and a config file to manage my plugins, and pull down updates to them from the associated git/hg repos.
(I was very inspired by https://github.com/hariton/pathogenized, which is excellent, but I wanted something slightly different and more python)
Here's a tutorial for getting your .vimrc and plugins under version control: http://vimcasts.org/episodes/synchronizing-plugins-with-git-submodules-and-pathogen/
One thing that is troubling is that while Linux and Mac can load up Vim with a few plugins pretty quickly, Cygwin on Windows just crawls trying to load anything at all.

One of the frustrating things I've found when trying to put my dot-files out there in a repo is that I'm in a weird predicament of having Vim installed on several computers, all of which are one of the popular flavors (Mac, Win, Linux).
@klauern, just use if statements in your vimrc
So I have three branches and a master for my git repo.

The frustrating thing is that If I think something's really neat to include in my vim, I have to consider whether it's platform-independent enough...

But if it is, i put it in master and then have my branches merge to master
@myfreeweb I think that's where I'm heading with that. I've already separated my .vim directory into it's own dot-file repo from the rest of my dot-files.
I use vimpyre+pathogen to manage my plugins. I've given up on source control for .vim/ and have moved it over to my Dropbox with symlinks out to ~/.vim/ and ~/.vimrc
http://pypi.python.org/pypi/vimpyre

@klauern, I store versions of dotfiles for each of the OSes I use, and have some scripts like "setup_osx.sh" that symlink the approprate versions for the appropriate systems.  For vimrc, I have conditional statements inside it.
@klauern I noticed that as well. I have several plugins I load in from Pathogen and it takes forever to start up.

@smerrell it's probably my biggest problem with Cygwin currently.  I don't think the Cygwin folks can do much about it, either, because they're trying to keep a POSIX layer of compatibility with Windows, such that you end up having to convert all paths from what it's mapped as on Windows (C:\cygwin\file\something) to something on Cygwin (/file/something) and back again.  It seems very much like magic, and as such it's probably not that fast...
Well if I had to run windows (and thankfully I do not) I would probably stick to a vm for dev stuff.
@RobertKern, I have my dotfiles git repo in dropbox. They work fine together. Never give up :)
And I got deep into yak shaving problems with the VM that made me wonder whether I was getting anything for having a separate OS on my computer
@ptone that sounds easy, but for me, that road was paved with just good intentions...
@myfreeweb, I guess I meant that I gave up on using source control to synchronize between work and home. I don't have that many other machines I need to put Vim on regularly.

All my dotfiles are in a git repo: https://github.com/jb55/dotfiles . I have a script that symlinks them into my home directory, deploying on a new system is just a matter of running the script. git pull keep everything up to date afterwards. I also use pathogen and store vim plugins as git submodules in the .vim/bundle directory.

I have my vim configuration here https://github.com/mrtazz/vimfiles. The main repository only contains the vimrc and the pathogen plugin. All other plugins are added as git submodules. This makes it rather easy for me to update or remove plugins. I usually have it cloned to ~/.vim and ~/.vimrc symlinked to ~/.vim/vimrc.
In the past I made $HOME a git repo, that was a bad idea
I keep a dotfiles git repo that includes a Makefile for setting up symlinks
@dag Makefile sounds like a good idea.

For me the real trick was to put all of my dotfiles in git, and keep all my vim plugins as submodules that pathogen.vim would load. This makes it easy to add and remove plugins and keep rest of my vim configs clean. http://github.com/csexton/dotfiles
@klauern Agreed. And I'll take the slow loading vim any day to have my POSIX layer in WIndows. I can't function in Windows without Cygwin :)
@RobertKern What does vimpyre buy you exactly? I don't quite get it, based on the example on PyPI.
my setup is here in case anyone is curious: https://github.com/durdn/cfg
@klauern I have solved your same problem not with branches but with the use of conditionals in my .vimrc like: if has('unix') , if has('gui_macvim'), if has('gui_win32'), etc...
@klauern and I do the same thing for my .bashrc for example:  if [ $(uname) == "Darwin" ]; then
@dwf vimpyre let's you search for, install and uninstall vim packages from the command line.
@RobertKern Hmm, I thought that's what pathogen did. Reading up on it I see I was mistaken. Time to start playing with it.

@durdn my setups for macvim and gvim are so different that I have a separate mvimrc and gvimrc, then symlink the correct one for each platform I am on. I try to keep all same stuff in plain console vimrc, all are available, along with plugins at http://bitbucket.org/nuclearsandwich/vimfiles, they are especially useful for Ruby and Ruby on Rails developers. There is a git mirror at gh:nuclearsandwich/vimfiles but I haven't been maintaining my .gitmodules, so you'd have to update submodules before use. I should write a script that syncs the two.
https://github.com/yannk/dotfiles-yann
Github. Awwww yeah. https://github.com/jmcantrell/dotfiles-vim
I keep mine in Dropbox along with other config dotfiles and a script that symlinks to them and installs some essential base packages.

I keep mine in Github and also use Vundle for managing outside bundles (used git submodules for that before). Works like a charm, especially that I switch between couple of computers with Vim. https://github.com/mariusz/vimfiles
@dwf vimpyre : pathogen :: apt : dpkg

@RobertKern I see. That's a useful analogy, thanks. And does it use/ does it expect you to also use a git repo to store the particular configuration of your plugins, doing some subrepo magic to keep track of sources, or does it just use git in a pull-only fashion? (I know you said that in your case you just use Dropbox.) Perhaps I should just install it already.
